title: Kenya: Private Schools Split Over Uhuru Order to Close
text:
Kenya: 500,000 Teenagers Infected With HIV 
The government's decision to close all schools has divided private schools, with some threatening to sue the state. 
On Friday, the state ordered all schools closed starting today, following the teachers' strike that enters week four. 
Some private schools have said they will obey the directive, while some have asked students to report to school as usual. 
Most private schools say it would difficult to comply with the directive without official communication. 
Visa Oshwal Schools, Waridi Schools and Acacia Crescent urged parents to disregard the directive and take children to school. 
Some parents are demanding school fees refund. 
Martin Andati yesterday said he had paid more than Sh100,000 and he doesn't understand the logic in closing private schools. He threatened to sue the state. 
Education ministry PR officer Kennedy Buhere said the directive affects only schools that offer 8-4-4 system and are registered with the Kenya National Examinations Council. 
Schools that offer international curriculum will operate as usual. 
The opposition has opposed the directive to close schools and have called for a public rally on Wednesday at Uhuru Park to compel the state to pay teachers the court-ordered 50-60 per cent salary hike. Kenya
